data.title: Major Anselm Tupper
data.meta_description: Anselm Tupper (1763–1808) was an officer of the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War, a pioneer to the Ohio Country, and one of the founders of Marietta, Ohio, the first permanent American settlement in the Northwest Territory. The eldest son of Benjamin Tupper, Anselm enlisted in the fight for independence during 1775, while only eleven years old, achieving the rank of lieutenant before his seventeenth birthday. After the war, he was a pioneer and surveyor in the Northwest Territory, and became major of the militia at Marietta during the Northwest Indian War. Tupper was the first school teacher at Marietta, and was a classical scholar and poet. He was unmarried, and was known as a favorite in society. Contents 1Early life and the American Revolutionary War 2Post-war and the Ohio Country 3References 4External links 5Bibliography Early life and the American Revolutionary War: Anselm Tupper was born in Easton, Massachusetts on October 11, 1763[1] and grew up to the age of eleven in Chesterfield in western Massachusetts. His childhood was brief, as Anselm Tupper enlisted in May 1775 at the young age of eleven, shortly after the Battles of Lexington and Concord,[2][3] likely being one of the younger soldiers in the fight for independence. Anselm joined Captain Robert West's Chesterfield company, assigned to Colonel John Fellows' regiment (17th Massachusetts Bay Provincial Regiment), in which Anselm's father, Benjamin Tupper, was already major.[3] As described in Chaffin's History of the Town of Easton, Massachusetts: It is interesting to think of this Revolutionary soldier, not yet twelve years old, engaging in all the toil, hardship, and peril of war, and never flinching until his country's independence was achieved.[4] During 1779, Anselm Tupper was appointed adjutant[5] of Colonel Ebenezer Sproat's (aka Sprout) regiment. Anselm was appointed ensign during 1779[4] or 1780.[2] He was subsequently promoted to the rank of lieutenant and adjutant in the 11th Massachusetts Regiment on September 1, 1780,[2][6] before his seventeenth birthday. He then served in the 10th Massachusetts Regiment during 1781 and 1782, the 6th Massachusetts Regiment during the first half of 1783, and the 2nd Massachusetts Regiment from June until November 3, 1783.[6] Post-war and the Ohio Country: During 1786, Rufus Putnam and Benjamin Tupper founded the Ohio Company of Associates. During that year, Anselm joined his father in a survey of the Seven Ranges in the Ohio Country.[5][7][8] Anslem became a shareholder of the Ohio Company of Associates, and was engaged as a surveyor with the company.[9] Subsequently, on April 7, 1788, Anselm Tupper and a group of American pioneers to the Northwest Territory, led by Rufus Putnam, arrived at the confluence of the Ohio and Muskingum rivers to establish Marietta, Ohio as the first permanent American settlement in the Northwest Territory.[10][11] Anselm's parents, Benjamin and Huldah, arrived several months later. Anselm Tupper was a notable member of the pioneer settlement of Marietta, and a favorite in society.[5] During September 1788, he served as a juror on the Grand Jury of the first civil court in the Northwest Territory.[12] During the Northwest Indian War in 1789, he was appointed major in the militia with command of the Campus Martius fortification during the war.[5][7] He was a founding member of the Society of the Cincinnati,[13] and an original member of the American Union Lodge No. 1 of Freemasons at Marietta[14] along with others including Rufus Putnam, Benjamin Tupper, and William Stacy. Anselm Tupper was the second officer of the vessel Orlando, built at Marietta in 1803; he sailed with the Orlando from Marietta down the Ohio and Mississippi rivers, across the Atlantic, and through the Mediterranean and Adriatic seas to Trieste.[15][16] He then returned home to Marietta. He was the first school teacher in Marietta and the Northwest Territory,[17][18] was a classical scholar, and was also a poet.[16][19] Anselm Tupper died on December 25, 1808. He is buried with his father and many other American Revolutionary War soldiers and pioneers at Mound Cemetery in Marietta.[20] Chaffin, History of the Town of Easton, Massachusetts, 255. Massachusetts Soldiers and Sailors, Vol 16, 143-44. Chaffin, History of the Town of Easton, Massachusetts, 255-56. Chaffin, History of the Town of Easton, Massachusetts, 256. Cutler, The Founders of Ohio, 26. Heitman, Officers of the Continental Army, 551. Howe, Historical Collections of Ohio, Vol. III, 509. Smith and Vining, American Geographers, 1784-1812, 214, 279. Hulbert, Proceedings of the Ohio Company, Volume I, 26. Hildreth, Pioneer History, 206. Hulbert, Proceedings of the Ohio Company, Volume I, 24. Hildreth, Pioneer History, 232-33. Drake, Memorials of the Society of Cincinnati, 489. Summers, History of Marietta, 294–95. Andrews, History of Marietta and Washington County, 880-81. Chaffin, History of the Town of Easton, Massachusetts, 257. Venable, Beginnings of Literary Culture in the Ohio Valley, 182-183. Birthplace of the Northwest Territory, 45. Barker, Recollections of the First Settlement of Ohio, 31-33. Hawley, Mound Cemetery, 443. | BillionGraves
data.text:
Description

Benjamin: General of the Army of the American Revolution, born at Sharon, Mass.; Huldah: wife of Benjamin, born at Bridgewater, Mass.; Anselm: Major of the Army of the American Revolution, born at Easton, Mass., emigrated to Marietta 1788 where he served as commander of the Stockade Fort, Campus Martius, Benjamin ... born in Sharon, Mass.

Hulda ... wife of Benjamin ... born in Bridgewater, Mass.

Anselm ... born in Easton, Mass. Emigrated to Marietta 1788 where he served as commander of the stockade Fort Campus Martius. , sons and daughters of Benjamin and Huldah Tupper
